text: [MANU-1.1] Text: The self-existent Lord created the waters and placed in them his seed, which became a golden egg.
[MANU-4.138] Text: Let one always speak what is true, and say what is pleasant; let him not utter an unpleasant truth.
[MANU-6.92] Text: Just as a chariot moves by means of wheels, so does a man move toward liberation by truth and duty.
[BG-1.1] Book: Bhagavad Gita Chapter: 1 Verse: 1 Text: Dhritarashtra said: In the holy plain of Kurukshetra, gathered together and eager for battle, what did my people and the Pandavas do, O Sanjaya?
[BG-1.2] Text: Sanjaya said: Seeing the army of the Pandavas drawn up for battle, King Duryodhana approached his teacher Drona and spoke these words.
[BG-1.3] Text: Behold, O Teacher, this mighty army of the sons of Pandu, arranged for battle by the son of Drupada, your wise disciple.
[BG-1.20] Text: At that time, Arjuna, whose chariot bore the banner of Hanuman, took up his bow and prepared to fight as the sound of conches filled the sky.
[BG-2.7] Text: My very being is afflicted by weakness and confusion. I ask you to instruct me clearly what is best. I am your disciple; teach me, for I have surrendered unto you.
[BG-2.11] Text: The wise grieve neither for the living nor for the dead.
[BG-2.13] Text: Just as the soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, it similarly passes into another body at death. The wise are not deluded by this.
[BG-2.47] Text: You have a right only to your actions, never to their fruits. Do not let the fruits of action be your motive, nor give attachment to inaction.
[BG-3.19] Text: Therefore, always perform your duty without attachment, for by performing actions without attachment, one attains the Supreme.
[BG-4.7] Text: Whenever righteousness declines and unrighteousness rises, then I manifest Myself age after age.
[BG-4.38] Text: Verily, nothing in this world is so purifying as knowledge. One who is perfected in yoga finds this knowledge within himself in due time.
[BG-6.5] Text: Let a man lift himself by his own self. Let him not degrade himself. For the self alone is the friend of oneself, and the self alone is the enemy of oneself.
[BG-12.13] Text: He who hates no creature, who is friendly and compassionate, free from possessiveness and egoism, balanced in pleasure and pain, and forgiving — such a devotee is dear to Me.
[MBH-ADI-1] Text: Ugrasrava Sauti recited the tale of the Bharatas to the sages assembled in the Naimisha forest.
[MBH-SABHA-12] Text: In the dice hall, Yudhishthira lost his kingdom, his brothers, and even Draupadi due to the deceit of Shakuni.
[MBH-VANA-47] Text: Arjuna received celestial weapons from Indra after performing severe austerities.
[MBH-BHISHMA-23] Text: Seeing the opposing armies, Arjuna’s limbs trembled, and he cast aside his bow, overwhelmed with sorrow.
[MBH-SALYA-61] Text: Bhishma lay upon a bed of arrows, instructing Yudhishthira in the duties of kings.
[VP-1.1] Text: Maitreya said to Parasara: “How did creation arise, and what is the nature of the Supreme Being?”
[VP-1.2] Text: Parasara replied: “Vishnu alone is the cause of all causes. From Him this universe manifests, is sustained, and is dissolved.”
[VP-2.4] Text: Time moves in cycles, and the universe follows the rhythms of creation and dissolution.
[RAMA-1.1] Text: Valmiki asked Narada: “Who among men is full of virtues, brave, truthful, firm in vow, compassionate, learned, and pleasing in appearance?”
[RAMA-1.2] Text: Narada replied: “There is a prince named Rama, born in the Ikshvaku line, who possesses all these qualities.”
[RAMA-2.18] Text: When Rama was exiled, the people of Ayodhya lamented, saying, “A kingdom without Rama is like a forest.”
[RAMA-3.11] Text: Ravana, filled with arrogance, abducted Sita, believing himself invincible.
[RAMA-6.128] Text: Rama returned to Ayodhya and was crowned king. The people rejoiced, and righteousness flourished.
[ISHA-1] Text: All this whatsoever moves in the universe is pervaded by the Lord. Enjoy through renunciation. Do not covet anyone’s wealth.
[ISHA-2] Text: One may desire to live a hundred years if one performs one’s duties. Thus action does not bind the one who performs them without attachment.
[ISHA-4] Text: The Self is unmoving, yet swifter than the mind. The senses cannot reach it, for it ever goes before them.
[ISHA-5] Text: It moves, and it moves not. It is far, and yet it is near. It is within all this, and yet it is outside all this.
[ISHA-6] Text: A wise man sees all beings in his own Self and his own Self in all beings. Then he does not hate or reject anyone.
[ISHA-7] Text: When to the knower all things become one with his own Self, then what delusion, what sorrow can there be?
[KATHA-1.1.1] Text: Nachiketa once asked Death: “When a man dies, some say he still exists, while others say he does not. Teach me the truth.”
[KATHA-1.2.18] Text: The Supreme Self is not born, nor does it die. It does not arise from anything, nor does anything arise from it. It is eternal and unchanging.
[KATHA-1.3.3] Text: The Self is difficult to understand, subtle and mysterious. Only a discerning person can comprehend it when taught by a wise teacher.
[KATHA-2.3.10] Text: Beyond the senses are their objects, beyond the objects is the mind, beyond the mind is the intellect, and beyond the intellect is the Great Self.
[KATHA-2.3.17] Text: When all desires that dwell in the heart are cast away, then the mortal becomes immortal and attains Brahman here.
